awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: Improving Research Coordination for Summit Station and the Dry-Snow Zone of Greenland
awd_abstract_narration:
Summit Station (72N, 38W, 3250 m.a.s.l.) hosts the Greenland Environmental Observatory, a cooperation between the National Science Foundation and the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration with permission from the Danish Commission for Scientific Research in Greenland to provide long-term environmental measurements. Summit is the only year-round, high-elevation, free-tropospheric, inland environmental observatory in the Arctic, and fills a unique niche in the international scientific community's global observing system. The Summit Station Science Coordination Office is an advisory body that serves the scientific community, the National Science Foundation's Arctic Research Support and Logistics Program and the Arctic Research Support & Logistics Services contractor by making recommendations about ways to accommodate or mitigate conflicting requests from different science teams working at Summit and suggesting ways that projects might reduce their logistical footprint. The Science Coordination Office also suggests science-based priorities for capital investments by the National Science Foundation at Summit. The Science Coordination Office strives to develop a true community of Summit users through open communication and by encouraging shared use of resources and key data sets. It also endeavors to focus the Summit community on the transformative questions identified by the participants at the Summit Station Science Summit in March 2017 and encourages the community to synthesize available data to identify innovative approaches to address these knowledge gaps.
     
The Science Coordination Office advances discovery and understanding of processes acting across the interior of the Greenland Ice Sheet while promoting teaching, training, and learning. New features of the GEO Summit website, aimed specifically at new Principal Investigators, will provide rich web content for interested students and the general public.  Over the next three years opportunities to interface with the new Greenland Climate Research Centre in Nuuk and add website content tailored to Greenlandic students and researchers will be actively pursued. The ability to quickly link to content about Summit Station will enable outreach programs by Summit researchers to increase their impact. Much effort in this project will be placed towards encouraging broad dissemination of results to enhance scientific and technical understanding. This will be accomplished by continuing to provide a clearinghouse for accessing Summit data, an extensive Summit bibliography, and a detailed list of planning activities to avoid duplicate collection of data at Summit. The Science Coordination Office will also provide greater visibility to the broader community by chairing sessions at international meetings and hosting data workshops that focus on Greenland.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Summit Station is the only year-round, high-elevation, free-tropospheric, inland environmental observatory in the Arctic. The NSF OPP Arctic Research Support and Logistics (RSL) program operates Summit Station.  OPP’s Arctic Science section and other programs in NSF, plus NASA, NOAA and international agencies have funded substantial scientific activities at Summit Station, Greenland for nearly 35 years.

The Summit Station Science Coordination Office (SCO) serves the Summit science community and RSL. A major objective of the SCO is to promote and help to advance RSL’s vision for Summit “to become an efficient, flexible observing platform supporting seasonal campaigns for research and training as well as a variety of research fields utilizing state-of-the-art technology to enable year-round measurements made autonomously or with minimal human presence.”  Related to this vision are goals of promoting sustainability and long-term resiliency for the station and the science conducted at the station through 1) long-range planning activities, 2) operational planning of seasonal and annual science and logistics activities and 3) promoting science community outreach and communication.

The past three years have been exciting in terms of long-range planning, as a major recapitalization project to relocate all station infrastructure onto elevated platforms approximately 2 km north east of the current station has begun. SCO has helped to develop a Long-Range Plan to accomplish the recapitalization project while continuing to support science, provided substantial input into the design of the planned new facilities, and contributed to the lengthy discussion about where to locate the new station.

Operational planning is essential to ensure that all science teams and science-dedicated staff deploying to Summit have the space and resources they require.  SCO works closely with Polar Field Services (PFS) staff to create seasonal support plans for each project. In addition, we provide input and guidance for proposed projects, like offering advice on location, available equipment, and resources. Over the past three years the SCO has assisted over 30 different research teams. SCO also worked with PSF to update north winds protocol (narrowing the bad air sector to reflect changes in the location of routine science and operational activities), devise project specific variants to this protocol, and started discussions about revised protocol specific to Recapitalization efforts that should lessen curtailment of work at the new site while protecting ongoing science in the clean air sector.

COVID presented considerable challenges for both science and operations, especially in 2020. SCO worked with RSL, PFS, and the science community to sustain year-round scientific observations at Summit with a much smaller summer-time crew.  We helped science teams develop plans to "winterize" all instruments as well as possible in case it was necessary to temporarily evacuate the station.  Fortunately, these plans were not needed.

SCO has continued to promote the value and use of Summit Station nationally and internationally despite the challenges of the pandemic. We have hosted or co-hosted several virtual workshops including annual virtual GEOSummit meetings and a Greenland fieldwork workshop sponsored by both NASA and NSF (Sept 14 and Sept 16, 2021). SCO members helped to organize the first workshop on the Future of Greenland Ice Sheet Science (FOGSS) on April 6-8, 2022, which is designed to combine the NSF GEOSummit and NASA Program for Arctic Regional Climate Assessment (PARCA) meetings for more efficient scientific planning for Greenland. SCO members presented updates to the Summit recapitalization plan as part of the FOGSS workshop. In addition, SCO members took part in and helped organize several other workshops to promote Summit Science including the National Academies of Science Polar technology workshop (May 5, 2022), an NSF-sponsored Scientific Traverses in Greenland planning workshop (June 11, 2021), a crevasse risk management and safety workshop (June 28-29, 2021), and polar radar technology conference (April 4-6, 2022), as well as several IARPC glacier workshops and an informational session for Jet Propulsion Lab researchers interested in doing “icy planets” fieldwork discussing Summit as a possible analog site (March 16, 2022). In addition, SCO is striving to foster greater collaboration with Greenlandic researchers and made presentations at Greenland Science Week December 1-5, 2019 and November 8-14, 2021.

SCO maintains the GEOSummit webpage that we update at least quarterly to include recent publications from projects conducted at Summit Station or making significant use of data collected at the station, current projects and happenings at the station, updates about meetings, and current data being collected at the station. During the reporting period, we updated the list of instruments and measurements at Summit, made it “searchable” and posted on GEOSummit web site. We also field questions and requests from the science community about the availability of data and help them navigate the various data bases housing the data. We provide links to all the available data on the website as well, and work to maintain access to those data.
